newsitem.title: USA: Mid-April freeze clouds US winter wheat estimates.
newsitem.headline: Mid-April freeze clouds US winter wheat estimates.

text.p: U.S. winter wheat production should exceed the 1996 crop, but damage from a mid-April freeze in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas impeded efforts to estimate the crop size, analysts said.

"Winter wheat production estimates at this stage of the growing season will be highly subject to further revisions by the USDA before the final crop estimates are released," said Jeff Wilson, analyst with Brock Associates.
"The freeze damage to the hard red winter wheat...will not be fully recognized until wheat harvesting begins," he said.

The U.S. Agriculture Department on Monday will release its first winter wheat crop estimate for 1997. An average of analysts' estimates indicated the USDA number may be near 1.574 billion bushels, up from last year's 1.478 billion.
Estimates for hard red winter wheat, which is mostly grown from Nebraska to Texas, ranged from 785 million to 949 million and averaged 894.3 million versus last year's harvest of 762.4 million.
A tour by crop specialists through Kansas this week estimated the freeze cut the crop 30 to 50 percent in southwest areas.
Late Thursday, the specialists estimated the Kansas crop at 336.2 million bushels, versus the 1996 dry-stressed reduced crop of 255.2 million.
Prior to the freeze, some crop experts said the Kansas crop could exceed 400 million bushels, the largest since the 1993 harvest of 433 million.
The lowest estimate in the Reuter survey was 1,453 million bushels by Dave Armstrong, analyst with ABN-AMRO Chicago Corp.
"I think the damage in Oklahoma and Texas was pretty severe," he said.
Oklahoma State University in late April estimated the freeze cut the state's crop to 121.34 million bushels from a pre-freeze estimate of 205.39 million.

Analysts estimates indicate a slight decrease in soft red winter and white winter wheat production. Analysts' SRW estimates ahead of Monday's USDA data averaged 417.4 million bushels versus 422.02 million a year ago and white winter wheat estimates averaged 262.1 million versus 293.63 million a year ago.
